title: Ardern steps up online content fight
text:
Wellington | The New Zealand government is spending millions of dollars on new investigators as it seeks to crack down on extremist online content.

Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern announced on Monday that $NZ17 million ($15.8 million) over four years would be spent improving resourcing for the country's chief censor and censorship compliance unit.

The resourcing is the latest response from the government to the Christchurch mosque attacks in March, when a gunman targeted and killed 51 Muslims during their time of prayer.

The shootings have transformed the availability of hate speech and communication between extremists to a top-line issue for the government.

It has already banned semi-automatic weapons and instituted a gun buyback scheme similar to the Australian regime in the aftermath of the 1996 Port Arthur attacks.

Ardern has also built a coalition of countries and tech multinationals to support the "Christchurch Call", which aims to ban the offensive material online, and is pursuing further gun law reform in parliament.
